docs.lead_paragraph: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has issued a statement saying that she looks forward to reviewing President Obama's proposal for compromise health care legislation, and reiterated the need to revamp the health system.

headline.main: Pelosi Taking a Long Look at President's Plan

docs.abstract: The House speaker says she is reviewing the president's proposal, which in many ways resembles the Senate's health care bill.
docs.snippet: The House speaker says she is reviewing the president's proposal, which in many ways resembles the Senate's health care bill.

docs.lead_paragraph: After more than a year of people talking about "President Obama's health care plan," the president actually has offered his own detailed proposal. And it's now posted on the White House Web site.

headline.main: White House Releases Health Care Plan

docs.abstract: The Obama administration rolled out its own proposal for a health care overhaul, an attempt to blend the House and Senate bills.
docs.snippet: The Obama administration rolled out its own proposal for a health care overhaul, an attempt to blend the House and Senate bills.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

docs.lead_paragraph: All eyes will be on the White House this morning as officials prepare to roll out President Obama's own comprehensive health care proposal, which is be posted on the White House Web site.

headline.main: White House Preparing to Roll Out New Health Plan

docs.abstract: President Obama will issue a detailed health care proposal this morning, to be posted at WhiteHouse.gov.
docs.snippet: President Obama will issue a detailed health care proposal this morning, to be posted at WhiteHouse.gov.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress returns from a blizzard-lengthened two-week break Monday, and the will Senate immediately face a crucial test vote on a stripped-down jobs measure.

headline.main: Congress Returns to Confront Jobs Bill

docs.abstract: The Senate is expected to take up a scaled-back employment bill, but the Democratic majority needs a few Republicans to get on board.
docs.snippet: The Senate is expected to take up a scaled-back employment bill, but the Democratic majority needs a few Republicans to get on board.

docs.lead_paragraph: Officials of the Health and Hospitals Corporation disagree with state officials on the size of cuts in aid for treating the poor.

headline.seo: New York City Public Hospitals Fear Huge Loss in State Money
headline.main: City’s Public Hospitals Fear Huge Loss in Subsidies
headline.print_headline: City’s Public Hospitals Fear Huge Loss in Subsidies

docs.snippet: Officials of the Health and Hospitals Corporation disagree with state officials on the size of cuts in aid for treating the poor.

docs.lead_paragraph: Governors said that they still needed help from the federal government but urged Congress to focus more on creating jobs in the private sector.

headline.main: With the Senate Set to Vote on Jobs Bill, Governors Say They Still Need Assistance
headline.print_headline: With the Senate Set to Vote on Jobs Bill, Governors Say They Still Need Assistance

docs.snippet: Governors said that they still needed help from the federal government but urged Congress to focus more on creating jobs in the private sector.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama will propose giving the federal government new power to block excessive rate increases by insurers as part of his health care bill.

headline.main: Obama to Urge Oversight of Insurers’ Rate Increases
headline.print_headline: OBAMA TO SEEK FEDERAL POWER OVER INSURERS

docs.snippet: President Obama will propose giving the federal government new power to block excessive rate increases by insurers as part of his health care bill.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: Five conservative thinkers outline the ideas they believe Republicans should offer to President Obama in Thursday’s health care meeting.

headline.seo: How the G.O.P. Can Fix Health Care
headline.main: How the G.O.P. Can Fix Health Care
headline.print_headline: How the G.O.P. Can Fix Health Care

docs.snippet: Five conservative thinkers outline the ideas they believe Republicans should offer to President Obama in Thursday’s health care meeting.

byline.original: By BILL FRIST, MARK McCLELLAN, JAMES P. PINKERTON,  CHARLES KOLB and NEWT GINGRICH

headline.content_kicker: Letters to the International Herald Tribune

docs.lead_paragraph: REPUBLICANS can't and won't accept a simple combination of the Democratic health care bills that passed the House and Senate. But the country needs health care reform, and Republicans must engage in the process. They should insist on adding reforms that would do more to reduce costs, in order to avoid higher income, payroll or similar taxes. (These taxes are different from the proposed excise tax on high-cost health insurance, which would actually reduce health-care spending.) Further cost-saving reforms could include meaningful changes in medical liability law; better opportunities for people to save money when they take steps to lower their health care costs; and Medicare savings from greater use of competitive bidding.

headline.main: How the G.O.P. Can Fix Health Care

docs.abstract: Mark B McClellan Op-Ed article maintains that Republicans cannot and will not accept simple combination of Democratic health care bills that passed House and Senate; asserts that Republicans should insist on adding reforms that would do more to reduce costs and make Medicare more sustainable while improving quality of care; drawing (M)
